ComicInfo.Title: 20th Century Eightball; About the Author; You; Grip Glutz and Shamrock Squid; Tom Pudd; Tits; Wallace Wood; Man-Child; Eightball; My Suicide…; The Sensual Santa; The Party; I Love You Tenderly; Paranoid; Playful Obsession; Curtain of Sanity; Ugly Girls; Grist for the Mill; Give it Up!; The Happy Fisherman; A Message to the People of the Future; The Operator; Sexual Frustration; On Sports; Why I Hate Christians; Chicago; Just Another Day…; Question Authority; Marooned on a Desert Island with the People on the Subway…; Frankie and Johnnie; I Hate You Deeply; Feldman; Needledick the Bug-Fucker; Devil Doll?; The Stroll; Ink Studs; The Truth; Ectomorph; Cool Your Jets; Art School Confidential; Twentieth Century Eightball (continued from back cover); Little Enid
ComicInfo.Summary:
Pogeybait comes back from school in his underwear and Zubrick is depressed.
Grip and Shamrock discuss old times.
Dan Clowes visits his characters.
The Sensual Santa goes about his business.
Dan goes to a party to meet some people, but they're not there.
Starts as a list of favourite people, then descends into another rant against people.
Squirrel Girl and Candy-Pants can't get a free coffee.
The desperate hunt for material.
What's the point of it all?
The Fisherman has trouble getting to the water.
Freddy has a new babysitter.
How all sports equates to sexual frustration.
Pogeybait's big date.
Why Dan hates Christians.
Clowes extols the virtues of his new home town.
Clowes directs his cast.
Hippypants and Peace Bear are out of touch with the times.
Clowes muses about being marooned with the people on his subway car.
An adaptation of the bawdy folksong using lyrics from the public domain book "Immortalia."
Zubrick's bad day.
Feldman blags a free coffee after getting the answer for a trivia question.
Needledick is unfulfilled.
A person walks home and relfects on the people and incidents they observe.
Why aren't artists figures of adoration?
Commentary on the art world.
The pain of being thin.
Lew wonders why he's never met his true love.
Clowes discusses the con of art schools.
